12:34.task: Chemistry - Simple equilibria and base-acid reactions

13:07.feedback: Components reversed: horizontal is vcos(theta), vertical is vsin(theta).

13:11.feedback: Correct. Also assumes no air resistance and constant gravitational field.

13:15.feedback: Partially correct. SUVAT is used, but the answer needs the specific vertical-motion reasoning.

13:19.feedback: Correct: range = horizontal velocity × time of flight.

13:23.feedback: Correct. Motions are independent because forces act on separate axes.

13:27.task: Projectile Motion - Effect of air resistance
13:27.feedback: Correct. Air resistance reduces horizontal range and maximum height.

13:31.task: Projectile Motion - Angle for maximum range
13:31.feedback: Correct for ideal projectile motion: 45 degrees gives maximum range.

13:36.feedback: Almost correct. Missing the 1/2. Formula is 1/2 I omega^2. I is moment of inertia, not impulse.

13:41.feedback: Rotational KE depends on angular velocity and moment of inertia; translational KE depends on linear velocity and mass.

13:46.task: Rotational KE - Effect of moment of inertia
13:46.feedback: Incomplete. Moment of inertia determines resistance to angular acceleration.

13:51.task: Rotational KE - Solid vs hollow sphere
13:51.feedback: Moment of inertia is the rotational equivalent of mass — worth revisiting.

13:56.feedback: You indicated you didn’t understand — review energy distribution between translational and rotational KE.

14:01.task: Rotational KE - Larger I → slower acceleration
14:01.feedback: This indicates a gap in content coverage — mark for later study.

14:06.feedback: Close but incomplete. The curve flattens because resistance increases with temperature.

14:11.feedback: Partially correct. A diode conducts when forward-biased due to the p-n junction barrier.

14:16.feedback: Incorrect. Thermistors are non-ohmic; their resistance changes with temperature.

14:21.feedback: Close. Non-ohmic means current is not proportional to voltage.

14:26.feedback: Incorrect. Semiconductors do not become superconductors; resistance decreases due to more charge carriers.

14:36.feedback: Very good description of the method.

14:41.task: Young Modulus - Thin and long wire

14:46.feedback: Correct. It’s the point where Hooke’s law stops applying.

14:56.feedback: Correct definition: plane-polarised light vibrates in a single plane.

15:00.task: Physics - polarisation: how a polarising filter works
15:00.feedback: Incorrect. A polarising filter absorbs oscillations in all but one plane; it does not rely on reflection at 45°.

15:04.task: Physics - polarisation: why only transverse waves can be polarised
15:04.feedback: Correct. Only transverse waves have oscillations perpendicular to motion that can be restricted to a plane.

15:08.feedback: Partially correct. Polarised sunglasses block horizontally-polarised reflected light to reduce glare.

15:12.task: Physics - polarisation: two filters at 90 degrees
15:12.feedback: Correct. Perpendicular filters block all light.

15:16.feedback: Incorrect. Snell's law is n1*sin(theta1) = n2*sin(theta2). You mixed it with the critical angle formula.

15:20.feedback: Partially correct. Refractive index is c/v, where v is the speed of light in the material.

15:24.feedback: Incorrect. TIR occurs when light travels from a denser to a less dense medium and the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle.

15:28.task: Physics - refraction: bending towards the normal
15:28.feedback: Partially correct. Light slows down in a denser medium, causing the wavefront to pivot toward the normal. Wavelength decreases, not increases.

15:32.feedback: Mostly correct. Optical fibres rely on repeated total internal reflection inside a high-index core surrounded by lower-index cladding.

15:36.task: Physics - Energy levels in atoms: quantised energy levels
15:36.feedback: Correct. Electrons occupy discrete energy levels and require specific quanta to move between them.

15:40.task: Physics - Energy levels in atoms: absorption spectra
15:40.feedback: Mostly correct. Absorption occurs when electrons absorb photons matching the energy gap between levels.

15:44.task: Physics - Energy levels in atoms: photon emission
15:44.feedback: Partially correct. Electrons emit photons to release the exact energy difference between levels.

15:48.task: Physics - Energy levels in atoms: wavelength of emitted radiation
15:48.feedback: Partially correct. Wavelength depends on the energy difference between levels via E = hc/λ.

15:52.task: Physics - Energy levels in atoms: uniqueness of emission spectra
15:52.feedback: Correct. Each element has a unique electronic structure, giving unique spectral lines.

15:56.task: Physics - circular motion: definition of centripetal force
15:56.feedback: Correct. Centripetal force acts toward the centre of the circular path.

16:00.task: Physics - circular motion: why no work is done
16:00.feedback: Incorrect. No work is done because centripetal force is perpendicular to velocity.

16:04.task: Physics - circular motion: derivation of F = mv^2/r
16:04.feedback: Correct. Using a = v^2/r and F = ma gives F = mv^2/r.

16:08.task: Physics - circular motion: factors affecting centripetal acceleration
16:08.feedback: Incorrect. Centripetal acceleration depends on speed and radius, not mass.

16:12.task: Physics - circular motion: why objects feel heavier at the bottom
16:12.feedback: Incorrect. Objects feel heavier because tension/normal force must exceed weight to provide centripetal force.

18:42.task: Physics - refraction: bending towards the normal
18:42.feedback: Clear improvement. You now understand that the wavefront pivots because one side slows first.

18:48.task: Physics - refraction: wavelength and frequency changes
18:48.feedback: Correct: frequency stays constant, wavelength decreases in denser media.

18:55.feedback: Good understanding of critical angle and why TIR only occurs from dense to less dense.

19:03.feedback: Solid grasp of doping with group 3 and 5 elements and why holes/electrons form.

19:10.feedback: Improved understanding of fixed ions and the built-in electric field.

19:18.task: Physics - semiconductors: forward and reverse bias
19:18.feedback: Correct: forward bias pushes carriers toward the junction, shrinking the depletion region.

19:26.task: Physics - circular motion: tension at the bottom of a vertical circle
19:26.feedback: You now understand why T = mg + mv^2/r and why objects feel heavier at the bottom.

21:16.feedback: Reviewed vertical velocity, time of flight, and independence of motions.

21:16-2.feedback: Focused on formula, moment of inertia, and rolling without slipping.

21:16-4.feedback: Reviewed definitions, experiment setup, and thin wire reasoning.

21:16-6.feedback: Reviewed Snell’s law, refractive index, TIR, and optical fibres.

21:16-7.feedback: Covered absorption/emission spectra, photon emission, and wavelength relations.

21:16-8.feedback: Reviewed centripetal force, work done, and tension at bottom of circle.

21:16-9.feedback: Practiced discriminant, direct proof, exhaustion, contradiction, and counterexample.

21:16-10.feedback: Reviewed nucleic acids, cell structure, enzymes, and cell cycle.
